{
  "article_text": [
    "a quandle , which was introduced by joyce @xcite , is an algebraic object whose axioms are motivated by knot theory and conjugation in a group . in @xcite ,",
    "carter , jelsovsky , kamada , langford and saito introduced a quandle homology theory , and they defined the quandle cocycle invariants for classical knots and surface knots .",
    "the quandle homology is defined as the homology of a chain complex generated by cubes whose edges are labeled by elements of a quandle . on the other hand",
    "the group homology is defined as the homology of a chain complex generated by tetrahedra whose edges are labeled by elements of a group .",
    "so it is natural to ask a relation between quandle homology and group homology .",
    "this question also arises from the fact that the quandle cocycle invariants were defined as an analogue of the dijkgraaf - witten invariants , which are defined using group cocycles .    in @xcite",
    ", the authors defined a simplicial version of quandle homology and constructed a homomorphism from the usual quandle homology to the simplicial quandle homology .",
    "the important point is that this homomorphism gives a triangulation of a knot complement in algebraic fashion .",
    "this enables us to relate the quandle homology to the topology of knot complements .    in this paper",
    ", we apply the results of @xcite to construct quandle cocycles from group cocycles .",
    "first , we demonstrate how to give a quandle cocycle of the dihedral quandle @xmath1 from a group cocycle of the cyclic group @xmath2 for any integer @xmath0 in section [ sec : dihedral ]",
    ". we will show that a generator of @xmath6 gives rise to a non - trivial quandle 3-cocycle of @xmath7 .",
    "when @xmath3 is an odd prime , since @xmath4 , our quandle 3-cocycle is equal to a constant multiple of the mochizuki 3-cocycle @xcite up to coboundary .",
    "then we generalize the construction to wider classes of quandles .",
    "let @xmath8 be a group and @xmath9 be an element of @xmath8 , then the set @xmath10 forms a quandle by conjugation .",
    "( it is known by joyce @xcite that any faithful homogeneous quandle has such a presentation . ) when some obstruction in second cohomology vanishes , we will construct a quandle cocycle of @xmath11 from a group cocycle of @xmath8 .",
    "dually , we relate the quandle cycle associated with an arc and region coloring ( shadow coloring ) of a knot @xmath5 to a group cycle represented by a cyclic branched covering branched along @xmath5 .",
    "let @xmath12 be a diagram of @xmath5 . we can define the notion of arc and region colorings of @xmath12 by a quandle @xmath11 .",
    "a pair of an arc and a region coloring is called a _ shadow coloring_. we can associate a cycle of a quandle homology group to a shadow coloring of @xmath12 . using the homomorphism constructed in @xcite , we will construct a group cycle of @xmath8 represented by a cyclic branched covering branched along @xmath5 .",
    "this reveals a close relationship between the shadow cocycle invariant of a knot and the dijkgraaf - witten invariant of the cyclic branched cover .",
    "we remark that hatakenaka and nosaka defined an invariant of 3-manifolds called the",
    "_ 4-fold symmetric quandle homotopy invariant _ @xcite , based on the fact that any 3-manifold can be represented as a 4-fold simple branched covering of @xmath13 along a link . as an application",
    ", they showed that the shadow cocycle invariant of a link for the mochizuki @xmath14-cocycle is equal to a scalar multiple of the dijkgraaf - witten invariant of the double branched cover along the link .",
    "this paper is organized as follows . in section [ sec : group_homology ] , we recall the definition of group homology and show how to represent a group cycle by a triangulation with a labeling of its @xmath15-simplices .",
    "we give a presentation of the fundamental group of a cyclic branched covering branched along a knot in section [ sec : pres_of_cyc_bra_cov ] , which is independent from the other sections . in section [ sec : cyc_rep_by_cyc_bra_cov ] , we construct a group cycle represented by a cyclic branched cover .",
    "we recall the definition of quandles and their homology theory in section [ sec : quandle_and_homology ] .",
    "we review some results from @xcite in section [ sec : main_map ] and apply them to construct quandle cocycles of the dihedral quandle @xmath1 in section [ sec : dihedral ] .",
    "the reader who is interested in the form of the @xmath14-cocycle , consult ( [ eq : the_cocycle ] ) ( and ( [ eq : formula_of_d ] ) ) .",
    "we will generalize the construction to wider classes of quandles in section [ sec : gen_const ] . in section [ sec : quandle_cyc_as_cyc_bra_cov ] , we construct a group cycle represented by a cyclic branched covering from the quandle cycle associated with a shadow coloring .",
    "the reader who is only interested in the construction of quandle cocycles from group cocycles may skip sections [ sec : group_homology ]  [ sec : cyc_rep_by_cyc_bra_cov ] except  [ subsec : group_homology ] .    * acknowledgement *    the author thanks takefumi nosaka for useful discussions .",
    "he also thanks the referees for helpful comments to improve the exposition .",
    "the author is supported by jsps research fellowships for young scientists .",
    "in this section , we collect basic facts on group homology . in  [ subsec : group_homology ] , we review the definition of group homology .",
    "we refer to @xcite for details .",
    "the material discussed in  [ subsec : cycles_represented_by_triangulations ] and  [ subsec : group_cycles_and_representations ] was developed in @xcite .",
    "let @xmath8 be a group .",
    "let @xmath16 be the free @xmath17$]-module generated by @xmath18-tuples @xmath19 $ ] of elements of @xmath8 .",

    "it is known that the group homology using the normalized chain complex coincides with the homology using the unnormalized one . in the homogeneous notation",
    ", we factor out @xmath30 by the subcomplex generated by @xmath40 such that @xmath41 for some @xmath39 to define the normalized chain complex .    for a left @xmath17$]-module @xmath42",
    ", the group cohomology @xmath43 is defined as the cohomology of the cochain complex @xmath44}(c_n(g),n)$ ] .",

    "let @xmath54 be an @xmath18-dimensional simplex .",
    "we label the vertices of @xmath54 by @xmath55 .",

    "any face inherits a vertex ordering from the vertex ordering of @xmath54 i.e. @xmath57 with @xmath60 .",
    "let @xmath61 be a cw - complex obtained by gluing a finite number of @xmath18-dimensional simplices along their @xmath62-dimensional faces in pairs by simplicial homeomorphisms .",
    "we denote the @xmath63-skeleton of @xmath61 by @xmath64 .",
    "we assume that the gluing maps preserve the vertex orderings of the faces",
    ". then @xmath65 is homeomorphic to a topological @xmath18-manifold ( not orientable in general ) .",

    ", we have @xmath82 .",

    "since @xmath84 , @xmath62-dimensional faces cancel in pairs .",
    "gluing @xmath72 s along their faces according to such pairings , we obtain an @xmath18-cycle @xmath61 . at any @xmath62-simplex of @xmath61 ,",
    "there exist exactly two adjacent @xmath18-simplices .",
    "the labelings of the @xmath62-simplex derived from these two @xmath18-simplices coincide .",
    "thus we have a well - defined labeling of @xmath15-simplices @xmath85 satisfying ,    1 .   [ item : circle ] @xmath82 for any 2-dimensional face @xmath81 , 2 .   [",

    "since these orientations agree on face pairings , thus we have an orientation on @xmath61 .",

    "the number of @xmath18-simplices in @xmath12 coincides with the number of @xmath18-simplices in @xmath61 , in particular finite .",
    "we fix a base point @xmath97 in the interior of @xmath12 .",

    "the relations are given at any @xmath107-simplices , around which there are a finite number of @xmath102 s .",
    "fix an @xmath18-simplex @xmath54 in @xmath12 and a labeling of vertices of @xmath54 derived from @xmath89 . then @xmath18-simplices adjacent to @xmath54 inherit labelings of vertices from @xmath89 . in this way ,",
    "all vertices of @xmath12 are labeled by elements of @xmath8 .",
    "now consider the labeling of vertices of @xmath108 and @xmath109 .",
    "since these reduce to the same labeling of edges , they coincide up to left multiplication .",
    "therefore there exists an element of @xmath8 which sends the labeling of vertices of @xmath109 to the one of @xmath108 .",
    "denote the element by @xmath110 .",
    "this @xmath111 induces a homomorphism @xmath112 .",

    ", we obtain a labeling of @xmath15-simplices @xmath89 of @xmath61 .",
    "this gives rise to a @xmath8-valued @xmath15-cocycle @xmath89 and a homology class in @xmath114 .",
    "the @xmath8-valued @xmath15-cocycle @xmath89 is well - defined up to the coboundary action . a map @xmath115 acts on a @xmath8-valued @xmath15-cocycle @xmath89 as a coboundary action by @xmath116 we can show that the homology class obtained from @xmath89 does not change under the coboundary action .",
    "for any @xmath50 , the cycle corresponding to the representation @xmath117 is obtained from @xmath89 by the coboundary action by @xmath118 . as a result ,",
    "the homology class obtained from @xmath111 depends only on the conjugacy class of @xmath111 . for a closed oriented @xmath18-manifold @xmath26 and a representation @xmath119",
    ", we have a homology class defined by the image of the fundamental class @xmath120 $ ] under the map @xmath121 . when @xmath26 is homeomorphic to an ordered @xmath18-cycle @xmath61 , the homology class is represented by a @xmath8-valued @xmath15-cocycle @xmath89 of @xmath61 associated with @xmath111 .",
    "in this situation , we say that the homology class defined by @xmath26 and @xmath111 is _ represented _ by @xmath61 and @xmath89 .",
    "in this section , we give a presentation of the fundamental group of a cyclic branched covering from the wirtinger presentation .",
    "let @xmath5 be a knot in @xmath13 and @xmath12 be a diagram of @xmath5 .",
    "then @xmath122 is presented by generators and relations , called the wirtinger presentation .",
    "let @xmath123 be the generators of the wirtinger presentation , that correspond to the arcs of @xmath12 .",
    "each crossing ( figure [ fig : wirtinger_relation ] ) gives rise to a relation @xmath124 .    for any integer @xmath125 ,",
    "let @xmath126 be the @xmath127-fold cyclic covering of @xmath5 , i.e. the manifold corresponding to the kernel of @xmath128 putting back the knot @xmath5 to @xmath126 , we obtain the @xmath127-fold cyclic branched covering @xmath129 of @xmath5 .",
    "[ prop : presentation_of_pi_one ] @xmath130 has the following presentation : @xmath131 the inclusion map @xmath132 is given by @xmath133 if we take appropriate base points . by adding a relation @xmath134 , we obtain a presentation of @xmath135 .",
    "a method for obtaining a presentation of the fundamental group of a branched covering is given in @xcite .",
    "but we give a proof here because some techniques will be used to construct a group cycle represented by @xmath129 later .",
    "first , we construct a handle decomposition of the knot complement associated with the wirtinger presentation ( figure [ fig : trefoil ] ) .",
    "then we lift the handle decomposition to a handle decomposition of @xmath126 ( figure [ fig : lifted_splitting ] ) .",
    "after that , we read the relations given by attaching 2-handles .",
    "let @xmath136 be a regular neighborhood of @xmath5",
    ". we shall give a handle decomposition of @xmath137 .",
    "we represent @xmath13 by the one point compactification of @xmath138 .",
    "let @xmath139 and @xmath140 .",
    "we denote the equatorial sphere of @xmath13 by @xmath141 .",
    "put @xmath5 in a position such that the projection to @xmath142 has only double points .",
    "let @xmath18 be the number of the crossings of this projection .",
    "we deform @xmath5 in the @xmath143-direction so that @xmath5 intersects @xmath142 at @xmath144 points and each of @xmath145 consists of @xmath18 arcs .",
    "we call @xmath146 over - crossing arcs and @xmath147 under - crossing arcs .",
    "index the arcs of @xmath148 by @xmath100 @xmath149 .",
    "now @xmath150 is homeomorphic to a handlebody of genus @xmath18 ( see figure [ fig : trefoil ] ) . projecting the over - crossing arcs to @xmath142 , we obtain a meridian disk system of the handlebody .",
    "we denote the meridian disk corresponding to @xmath100 by @xmath151 . for each under - crossing arc , attach a 2-handle @xmath152 along @xmath153 to @xmath154 ( see figure [ fig : trefoil ] ) .",
    "then the resulting manifold is homeomorphic to @xmath155 where @xmath156 is a 3-ball . attaching @xmath156 along the boundary to @xmath157 , the resulting manifold is homeomorphic to @xmath137 .",
    "so we have a handle decomposition of @xmath137 into one 0-handle , @xmath18 1-handles , @xmath18 2-handles and one 3-handle . in this handle decomposition , 1-handles correspond to the wirtinger generators and 2-handles to the wirtinger relations .",
    "we denote the set of @xmath39-handles by @xmath158 and @xmath159 .",
    "next we consider the preimage of @xmath160 in @xmath126 .",
    "cut @xmath160 along the meridian disks @xmath151 , and denote the resulting manifold by @xmath161 , which is homeomorphic to a 3-ball .",
    "let @xmath105 be a point in @xmath162 .",
    "we take a loop in @xmath160 which starts at @xmath105 , then intersects the meridian disk @xmath151 and ends at @xmath105 .",
    "orient the loop so that it corresponds to the generator of @xmath163 . by abuse of notation",
    ", we also denote this loop by @xmath100 .",
    "take a lift @xmath164 of @xmath161 and denote the preimage of @xmath165 in @xmath166 by @xmath167 .",
    "then there exists a unique lift @xmath168 of the loop @xmath100 starting at @xmath167 . since @xmath100 corresponds to the generator of @xmath169 , @xmath168 ends at another lift of @xmath161 , we denote it by @xmath170 .",
    "similarly the lift of @xmath100 starting at @xmath170 ends at another lift , we denote it by @xmath171 . continuing this",
    ", we see that @xmath172 and all lifts of @xmath161 will appear .",
    "therefore the preimage of @xmath160 is decomposed into @xmath127 3-balls @xmath173 .",
    "the intersection of @xmath174 and @xmath175 consists of @xmath18 disks each of which is a lift of a meridian disk @xmath151 .",
    "we denote this lifted disk by @xmath176 ( figure [ fig : lifted_splitting ] ) .",
    "it is easy to check that @xmath177 forms a meridian disk system of the preimage of @xmath160 .",
    "denote the lift of @xmath100 starting at @xmath174 ( ending at @xmath175 ) by @xmath178 .",
    "then the generator of @xmath179 corresponding to the meridian disk @xmath176 is given by @xmath180 we denote this element by @xmath181 . to give a simple presentation of @xmath179",
    ", we add extra generators @xmath182 corresponding to @xmath183 respectively and relations @xmath184 .",
    "finally we consider the relations given by the lifts of 2-handles .",
    "we see that the relation @xmath124 lifts to @xmath185 see figure [ fig : lifted_splitting ] .    since the generator @xmath181 is represented by ( [ eq : generator_in_cyclic_cover ] ) , the inclusion map @xmath186 is given by @xmath187 .",
    "this proves the second statement .    by adding a 2-handle to @xmath126 along @xmath188 and capping off the resulting sphere , we obtain a manifold homeomorphic to the cyclic branched covering @xmath129",
    ". therefore a presentation of the cyclic branched covering is obtained by adding a relation @xmath134 .",
    "for a representation @xmath189 , we have the restriction map @xmath190 given by @xmath191 if @xmath192 , it reduces to a representation @xmath193 and there is a group cycle given by @xmath194 and @xmath195 . in this section ,",
    "we construct an explicit ordered @xmath14-cycle and its @xmath8-valued @xmath15-cocycle representing the homology class given by @xmath194 and @xmath195 .",
    "first we give a triangulation of @xmath137 associated with the wirtinger presentation .",
    "ll ( a ) & ( b ) +    &     + & + ( c ) & ( d ) +    &     + ( e ) & +    let @xmath5 be a knot and fix a diagram of @xmath5 .",
    "as in the proof of proposition [ prop : presentation_of_pi_one ] , we define @xmath196 and give a heegaard splitting of @xmath154 with the meridian disks @xmath151 . cutting the handlebody @xmath154 along the meridian disks @xmath151 , the result is a ball with @xmath144 2-cells on the boundary .",
    "we denote the resulting 3-ball by @xmath161 and the pair of 2-cells corresponding to @xmath151 by @xmath108 and @xmath104 so that the wirtinger generator corresponding to @xmath100 runs from @xmath108 to @xmath109 ( figure [ fig : cut_heegaard](a ) ) . now consider the attaching regions of the two handles corresponding to under - crossing arcs , which consist of annuli @xmath197 on @xmath198 .",
    "each annulus is divided by @xmath151 s into 4 rectangles on @xmath199 .",
    "we define a graph on @xmath199 with vertices consisting of @xmath99 and edges consisting of these rectangles ( figure [ fig : cut_heegaard](b ) ) .",
    "each vertex of this graph has valency at least four .",
    "we can make all vertices of the graph into trivalent vertices ( figure [ fig : cut_heegaard](c ) ) by adding extra @xmath15-handles and @xmath200-handles ( stabilizations of the heegaard splitting , see figure [ fig : stabilization ] ) .",
    "we denote the new vertices by @xmath201 , @xmath202 , ... which originally belonged to @xmath99 .",
    "the dual of the graph gives a triangulation of @xmath199 ( figures [ fig : cut_heegaard](d ) and [ fig : cut_heegaard](e ) ) . by abuse of notation , we denote the triangles dual to the vertices @xmath201 , @xmath202 , ... by the same symbols .",
    "taking a cone from an interior point of @xmath161 , we obtain a triangulation @xmath61 of @xmath161 into @xmath203 tetrahedra . regluing the triangles",
    "@xmath204 , @xmath205 , ... to @xmath206 , @xmath207 , ... , we obtain a triangulation of @xmath137 into @xmath203 tetrahedra , which was explained in @xcite .",
    "we remark that this is not a triangulation in the usual sense : it is not a simplicial complex , moreover the link of some @xmath208-simplex is not homeomorphic to the @xmath200-sphere .",
    "actually there exists only three @xmath208-simplices , one is the cone point in @xmath161 ( north pole in @xcite ) , second is the @xmath208-simplex corresponding to the complementary regions of the diagram ( south pole ) , the last one is a @xmath208-simplex whose small neighborhood is homeomorphic to the cone over the torus @xmath209 .    using this triangulation",
    ", we construct a triangulation of the cyclic branched covering @xmath129 .",
    "let @xmath210 be @xmath127 copies of @xmath161 and @xmath211 be the triangulation of @xmath174 we have constructed .",
    "we denote the triangles @xmath201 , @xmath202 , ... on @xmath212 by @xmath213 , @xmath214 , ... respectively . by abuse of notation ,",
    "we regard @xmath213 , @xmath214 , ... simply as @xmath215 .",
    "glue @xmath211 s along their boundary triangles by the following identification maps @xmath216 denote this triangulation by @xmath217 .",
    "we define an ordering of each tetrahedron by assigning @xmath208 to the interior vertex of @xmath174 , @xmath15 to the vertex corresponding to complementary region of the diagram , @xmath200 to the vertex corresponding to under - crossing arc , @xmath14 to the vertex corresponding to over - crossing arc , respectively ( figure [ fig : ordering ] ) .",
    "the orderings are compatible under the gluing maps .",
    "so @xmath217 is an ordered @xmath14-cycle .",
    "here @xmath217 is a triangulation of @xmath129 except near the @xmath208-simplex corresponding to @xmath5 , whose small neighborhood is homeomorphic to a cone over a torus .",
    "we can resolve this singularity by inserting a suspension of a @xmath218-gon around @xmath5 ( figure [ fig : prism ] ) . as a result , we obtain an ordered @xmath14-cycle homeomorphic to @xmath129 .",
    "( this procedure is called `` blowing up '' at a @xmath208-simplex in @xcite . )",
    "we construct a group cycle given by @xmath129 and a representation @xmath219 using the triangulation @xmath217 . here",
    "@xmath195 is given by the set @xmath220 satisfying @xmath221 give a labeling of vertices on @xmath211 for each @xmath222 .",
    "let @xmath223 be the labeling of vertices on @xmath224 and @xmath225 be the labeling of vertices on @xmath226 .",
    "if these are related by @xmath227 then we obtain a @xmath8-valued @xmath15-cocycle @xmath89 on @xmath217 by gluing @xmath211 using @xmath195 . to obtain a group cycle given by @xmath129 and @xmath195",
    ", we insert a suspension over a @xmath218-gon to @xmath217 at the @xmath208-simplex corresponding to @xmath5 .",
    "we give an ordering on the vertices of each tetrahedron of the suspension compatible with the ordering on the @xmath218-gon , e.g. order the central @xmath208-simplex maximal .",
    "these tetrahedra inherit a vertex labeling by @xmath8 on the boundary faces of the suspension .",
    "we assign any labeling at the central @xmath208-simplex of the suspension .",
    "then upper and lower tetrahedra have the same labelings with different orientations .",
    "so these cancel out in pairs and give no contribution to the group cycle represented by @xmath129 and @xmath195 .",
    "therefore the homology class given by @xmath217 and @xmath89 represents the homology class given by @xmath129 and @xmath195 .",
    "in this section , we review the definitions of quandles , rack ( co)homology and quandle ( co)homology . our treatment of quandle ( or rack ) homology follows that of @xcite . in  [ subsec : shadow ] and  [ subsec : cocycle_invariant ] , we recall the notions of colorings and quandle cocycle invariants defined in @xcite .      a _ quandle _ @xmath228 is a set with a binary operation @xmath105 satisfying the following axioms :    * @xmath229 for any @xmath230 , * the map @xmath231 defined by @xmath232 is a bijection for any @xmath233 , * @xmath234 for any @xmath235 .",
    "we denote the inverse of @xmath236 by @xmath237 . for a quandle @xmath228",
    ", we define the _ associated group _ @xmath238 by @xmath239 a quandle @xmath228 has a right @xmath238-action in the following way .",
    "let @xmath240 be an element of @xmath238 where @xmath241 and @xmath242 .",
    "define @xmath243 .",
    "one can easily check that this is a right action of @xmath238 on @xmath228 .",
    "so the free abelian group @xmath244 $ ] generated by @xmath228 is a right @xmath245$]-module .",

    "let @xmath228 be a quandle .",
    "let @xmath273 be an oriented link in @xmath13 and @xmath12 be a diagram of @xmath273 .",
    "an _ arc coloring _ of @xmath12 is an assignment of elements of @xmath228 to arcs of @xmath12 satisfying the following relation at each crossing ,    where @xmath274 . by the wirtinger presentation of the knot complement",
    ", an arc coloring determines a representation of @xmath275 into the associated group @xmath238 .",
    "this is obtained by sending each meridian to its color .",
    "let @xmath259 be a set with a right @xmath238 action .",
    "region coloring _ of @xmath12 is an assignment of elements of @xmath259 to regions of @xmath12 satisfying the relation    for any pair of adjacent regions , where @xmath276 and @xmath230 .",
    "a pair @xmath277 is called a _",
    "shadow coloring_. if we fix a color of a region of @xmath12 , then colors of other regions are uniquely determined .",
    "therefore there always exists a region coloring compatible with a given arc coloring .",
    "we define a cycle @xmath278 of @xmath279)$ ] for a shadow coloring @xmath280 . assign @xmath281 for a positive crossing and @xmath282 for a negative crossing colored by    respectively",
    ". then define @xmath283),\\ ] ] where @xmath284 .",
    "we can easily check that    [ prop : not_depend_on_region_coloring ] @xmath278 is a cycle and the homology class @xmath285 $ ] is invariant under reidemeister moves .",
    "moreover it does not depend on the choice of the region coloring if the action of @xmath238 on @xmath259 is transitive .",
    "so the homology class @xmath285 $ ] is an invariant of the arc coloring @xmath286 in many cases .",
    "there are two important sets with right @xmath238-action : one is when @xmath259 consists of one point @xmath287 and the other is when @xmath288 .",
    "eisermann showed that the cycle @xmath285 $ ] for @xmath289 is essentially described by the monodromy of some representation of the knot group along the longitude ( @xcite , @xcite ) .",
    "so we concentrate on the invariant @xmath285 $ ] in the case of @xmath288 from now on .",

    "let @xmath228 be a quandle and @xmath26 be a right @xmath245$]-module .",
    "we can construct a map from the rack homology @xmath514 to the group homology @xmath515 .",
    "the following lemma is well - known , e.g. see lemma 7.4 of chapter i of @xcite .",
    "let @xmath516 be a chain complex where @xmath517 are projective ( e.g. free ) .",
    "let @xmath518 be an acyclic complex .",
    "any homomorphism @xmath519 can be extended to a chain map from @xmath520 to @xmath521 .",
    "moreover such a chain map is unique up to chain homotopy .",
    "so there exists a unique chain map from @xmath522 to @xmath523 up to homotopy . this map induces @xmath524 }",
    "c^r_*(x ) \\to m \\otimes_{\\mathbb{z}[g_x ] } c_*(g_x)$ ] and then @xmath525 .",

    "this map induces a homomorphism @xmath537 , which is equal to the map we have constructed in this subsection .",

    "in particular , when @xmath3 is odd prime , @xmath543 vanishes for @xmath544 .",
    "in this section , we study the dual of the previous construction",
    ". we will show that the cycle @xmath278 associated with a shadow coloring @xmath277 of a knot @xmath5 gives rise to a group cycle represented by a cyclic branched covering along @xmath5 and the representation induced from the arc coloring @xmath286 .",

    "we end this section by comparing the shadow cocycle invariant of the @xmath393-torus knot ( @xmath3 : odd ) for the @xmath14-cocycle obtained in section [ sec : dihedral ] and the dijkgraaf - witten invariant of the lens space @xmath587 .",
    "let @xmath8 be a finite group and @xmath588 be a cocycle of @xmath589 where @xmath45 is an abelian group .",
    "dijkgraaf and witten defined an invariant of closed oriented 3-manifolds for each @xmath588 .",
    "for an oriented closed manifold @xmath26 , it is defined by @xmath590 \\rangle \\in \\mathbb{z}[a]\\ ] ] where @xmath591 is the pull - back of @xmath588 by the classifying map @xmath592 corresponding to @xmath111 . since @xmath587 is a double branched cover along the @xmath393-torus knot , the cycle obtained from a shadow coloring by @xmath1 gives rise to a group @xmath14-cycle of @xmath503 represented by @xmath587 by theorem [ thm : main_branched ] .",
    "since every representation of @xmath593 into @xmath503 reduces to a representation into @xmath2 , it is natural to ask whether the shadow cocycle invariant for our quandle @xmath14-cocycle coincides with the dijkgraaf - witten invariant for @xmath594 .",
    "as we remarked in the introduction , these invariants coincide up to some constant by the result of hatakenaka and nosaka @xcite when @xmath3 is prime .",
    "let @xmath280 be the shadow coloring indicated in figure [ fig:(2,p)-torus ] .",
    "since the homology class @xmath285 $ ] does not change under the action of @xmath1 on the shadow coloring @xmath280 ( see lemma 4.5 of @xcite ) , we assume that @xmath399 . as computed in  [ subsec:3_cocycle_of_dihedral ] , the evaluation of the @xmath278 at the @xmath14-cocycle derived from @xmath595 is equal to @xmath401 .",
    "therefore the shadow cocycle invariant is @xmath596/ ( t^p-1 ) \\cong \\mathbb{z}[\\mathbb{z}/p].\\ ] ]    we compute the dijkgraaf - witten invariant of the lens space @xmath597 for the group @xmath14-cocycle @xmath594 .",
    "although this was computed in @xcite , we give a proof based on a triangulation .",
    "we represent @xmath597 by an ordered @xmath14-cycle and give a labeling of @xmath15-simplices as indicated in figure [ fig : lens ] . here",
    "the triple @xmath598 , @xmath599 and @xmath412 must satisfy @xmath600 and @xmath601 .",
    "using multiplicative notation , the evaluating of @xmath595 on this cycle is @xmath602 ) = \\sum_{i=0}^{p-1 } a \\cdot b_2(ia+b , -q a ) = -q a^2.\\ ] ] the second equality follows form the fact that @xmath603 runs over @xmath2 and the equation ( [ eq:2_cocycle_of_cyclic_group ] ) when @xmath598 is a unit , and also when @xmath598 is not a unit by a similar argument .",
    "therefore the dijkgraaf - witten invariant of @xmath597 is equal to @xmath604/ ( t^p-1 ) \\cong \\mathbb{z}[\\mathbb{z}/p].\\ ] ] therefore this coincides with the shadow cocycle invariant up to a constant .",
    "99 d. j. benson , _ representations and cohomology i : basic representation theory of finite groups and associative algebras _",
    ", cambridge studies in advanced mathematics , 30 . cambridge university press , cambridge , 1991 .",
    "xii+224 pp .",
    "s. kamada , _ quandles with good involutions , their homologies and knot invariants _ , intelligence of low dimensional topology 2006 , 101108 , ser .",
    "knots everything , 40 , world sci .",
    "hackensack , nj , 2007 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we give a construction of quandle cocycles from group cocycles , especially , for any integer @xmath0 , quandle cocycles of the dihedral quandle @xmath1 from group cocycles of the cyclic group @xmath2 . </S>",
    "<S> we will show that a group 3-cocycle of @xmath2 gives rise to a non - trivial quandle 3-cocycle of @xmath1 . </S>",
    "<S> when @xmath3 is an odd prime , since @xmath4 , our 3-cocycle is a constant multiple of the mochizuki 3-cocycle up to coboundary . </S>",
    "<S> dually , we construct a group cycle represented by a cyclic branched covering branched along a knot @xmath5 from the quandle cycle associated with a colored diagram of @xmath5 . </S>"
  ]
}
